body:
To my knowledge it's not removed until PHP 5.5.

Anyway, for your code it should be using version_compare function

@aanbar  I'm sorry, my sys admin silence upgrade system and automaticaly installed php 5.5

Ok this fix for php 5.5 :)

You should be using the third argument in php_version function, in your example if the current version is exactly 5.5 it will return zero (your if statement will fail)

```
if ( version_compare(PHP_VERSION, '5.5', '>=') ) 
```

We have `is_php()` to check for the PHP version that you might find to be handy, but otherwise this is not at simple as it looks. Version checks are only useful for functions that act differently or that may not exist in a PHP version. Your proposed fix triggers a bigger problem - syntax. Anonymous functions are not available prior to PHP 5.3 and anybody using PHP 5.2.x won't be able to use CI with this change applied (and we do support 5.2).

@narfbg,

With that said, you are open to fixing this and recognize it as a problem, however, the author needs to (or another member) needs to account for anonymous function calls, correct?
Of course, if it wasn't a problem I'd have closed the issue. And since it is a problem, somebody has to fix it ... it doesn't matter who it is, we're all contributing in our spare time.

I guess we can make it work using "create_function" to create the anonymous function.

And since preg_replace_callback was introduced with php 4, a check for php version won't be needed; the use of preg_replace_callback would be sufficient.

Codeigniter is awesome, why fallback on php4? Why don't we create history?
By the way, who the hell still uses php4?

2013/10/18 aanbar notifications@github.com

> I guess we can make it work using "create_function" to create the
> anonymous function.
> 
> And since preg_replace_callback was introduced with php 4, a check for php
> version won't be needed; the use of preg_replace_callback would be
> sufficient.
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/EllisLab/CodeIgniter/issues/2681#issuecomment-26590557
> .
@inihan Just because something is available _since_ PHP 4, it doesn't mean that we're falling back to it.
The above commit fixes the issue by simply adding the semicolon and letting `html_entity_decode()` do the job.

issue.title: core/security PHP 5.5.x preg_replace(): The /e modifier is deprecated

body: This code also affects CI 2.x series and should be fixed within a minor bug release (as soon as possible!). The code instructions are not as precise, I have accomplished it this way https://github.com/inexor-game/community-site/commit/dcc7c541bebe183516d08899bff8c654ff4acb01
You should look into the 2.2.1 code, as soon as possible. ;)

Haven't seen the new release yet, ty! :+1: 
Can be closed, I guess.

issue.title: Fix CodeIgnitor preg_replace() "e" modifier feature which has been removed from PHP

issue.body:
As documented here https://github.com/bcit-ci/CodeIgniter/issues/2681

Here is the commit they merged.
https://github.com/inexorgame-obsolete/community-site-deprecated/commit/dcc7c541bebe183516d08899bff8c654ff4acb01

I don't think `entity_decode()` works at all on any install using PHP > 5.5 without this fix.
